13
Scheonle and Omnitims uf Mrizes
ALTITUDE CONTEST
World's Record Prize.
$5000.00
In case the world's record (11,474 ft.) is exceeded more than once during
the meet, for each succeeding new world's record made at San Francisco there
will be an additional prize of $1000, limited to the highest record each day.
DAILY ALTITUDE PRIZES
First Prize
$250.00
Second
Prize
125.00
Third Prize
50.00
Conditions:
To qualify and make these prizes available, at least three avia-
tors must reach an
altitude
exceeding 2000 feet, otherwise the daily altitude
prizes for that day will be withdrawn for lack of competition.
SPEED CONTEST
World's Record Prize.
$5000.00
Conditions:
To qualify at least two laps must be made on the 2.5 kilometer
course at a speed of not less than 50 miles per hour, by at least three aviators.
In case the world's speed record is exceeded more than once, for each suc-
ceeding new world's speed record, made at San Francisco, $1000 will be paid,
limited to the fastest record each day.
DAILY SPEED PRIZES
First Prize
$250.00
Second Prize
125.00
Third Prize
50.00
Conditions: To qualify and make these prizes available, at least three avi-
ators must each make three laps on the 2.5 kilometer course at a speed of not
less than 40 miles per hour, otherwise these daily speed prizes will be withdrawn
for lack of competition.
DAILY PASSENGER CARRYING CONTEST
First Prize
$250.00
Second Prize
125.00
Third Prize
50.00
Conditions: At least two aviators must qualify for each of these prizes,
each carrying the number of passengers called for by the prize for which they
are competing, by making three laps of the 2.5 kilometer course with passengers
weighing at least 125 pounds each.
The first prize will be given to the aviator making the greatest speed for
three laps with three passengers exclusive of operator.
The second prize will be given to the aviator making the greatest speed
for three laps with two passengers, exclusive of operator.
The third prize will be given to the aviator making the greatest speed for
three laps with one passenger, exclusive of operator.
If there be less than two aviators qualifying for any of these three passen-
ger carrying contests, the prize offered for such contest will be withdrawn for
lack of competition.

OFFICIAL SOUVENIR PROGRAM
Rules of the
Untest Cummittee Marift Aern Ulth
Trial Flights for Aermanti Direnses
(Preliminary:
Before a candidate
will be allowed to enter the
Trial Flights, a Preliminary Flight must be held in which the aviator
shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Committee that he can make
one continuous flight of 500 yards, and after stopping his engine, land
within a distance of 150 yards from a previously designated spot.)
RULE I
Three separate flights
must be made, each of five (5) kilometers
(approximately 3 1-10 miles) in a closed circuit without coming to the
ground.
These flights need not necessarily be made on the same day.
RULE II
On the completion of each circuit of five (5) kilometers, the en-
gine must be stopped and a landing effected within 150 yards of a given
spot previously designated by the candidate, and agreed to by the Offi-
cial Observer.
RULE III
Each of the three trials required of candidates must be vouched for
by officials appointed by the PACIFIC AERO CLUB. A separate of-
ficial certificate must be obtained for each flight.
RULE IV
All
trials
are under the control of and must be made in places
agreed to by the PACIFIC AERO CLUB, and in the presence of the
responsible officials appointed by the PACIFIC AERO CI.UB.
RULE V
Members of affiliated clubs can obtain Aeronautic Licenses
(for
Spherical and Dirigible balloons) and Aviators' Licenses from the PA-
CIFIC AERO CLUB upon receipt of certificates from their clubs to the
effect that they have fulfilled the conditions required by the Aero Club
of America for granting such licenses.
RULE VI
Applicants will be required to pay in advance the following ex-
-penses, to wit:
(a) Traveling expenses of the Contest Committee, (b)
Cost of a survey of local field where trial is held, and certificate of sur-
veyor authorized by the Committee.
This (clause b) will apply only in
case the trial flight is made on unofficial ground.
Contest Unmmitter
Dr. R. Cushing, Phelan Building, Phone Kearny 1755.
Mr. Cleve T. Shaffer, 441 Golden Gate Ave., Phone Park 7081.
Mr. Wm. J. Drew, 67 Buena Vista Terrace, Phone Park 4502.

AVIATION MEET, SAN FRANCISCO, 1911
Glem Gammand Ourtiss
Although few young men of his age have attained equal world wide
distinction, Glenn Hammond Curtiss, champion aviator at the age of
32, finds fame no new thing.
He was born in Hammondsport, New York, the son of a Meth-
odist minister, and was slated for the ministry.
As is characteristic of
him, however, he had his own way, and chose different lines.
At an
early period in his life, while attending the public schools, he began a
series of experiments in motors, with the end in view of applying a
small motor to a bicycle in order to facilitate the distribution of daily
newspapers by which means he was at that time earning a livelihood.
He was successful in this experiment continued along this line, so
that, at the age of 20, he had perfected a motor cycle of commercial
value.
Shortly afterwards he became a devotee of motorcycle racing.
In 1905 he won the first American track championship and two years
later, on a machine of his own construction, he traveled a mile at Or-
mond Beach, Florida, in the remarkable time of twenty-six and two-
fifths seconds.
This record still stands as the fastest mile ever trav-
eled by human being.
The aeroplane next came to the attention of Curtiss, and with oth-
ers he formed the Aerial Experiment
Association.
This association
designed and built the "White Wing," a biplane which made a number
of short flights.
This was followed by the "Red Wing," and later by
the "June Bug,"
which was the most successful machine in America
up to that time.
On July 4, 1908, Curtiss, flying the June Bug, won the Scien-
tific American Trophy, the first aeroplane prize ever offered in Amer-

OFFICIAL SOUVENIR PROGRAM
ica, by a flight of one mile straight away in a little less than two min-
He again won the Scientific American Trophy in 1909, at Mine-
ola, L. I.
At
Rheims,
France, he
competed with his own aeroplane,
equipped with a 60-horsepower Curtiss motor, and brought the Gordon-
Bennett Cup to America.
At Broscia, Italy, he won first prize for the
fastest flight of fifty kilometers.
In 1910, he established the world's record for quick start by leav-
ing the ground in four and one-fifth seconds from the time of starting
the motor.
His greatest feat was the winning of the New York World's $10,-
C00.00 prize by flying from Albany to New York.
Shortly after this feat, while at Hammondsport, N. Y., he conduct-
ed a series of bomb dropping experiments, the first ever tried.
an aeroplane designed especially for alighting on water, at a height be-
tween 500 and 1000 feet he scored thirteen hits out of seventeen shots,
a remarkable record.
At Atlantic City, during the recent Aviation Meet,
he
aston-
ished the officials by climbing to the height of 1500 feet in five minutes
and fifty-two seconds, the most rapid climb yet made.
Two days later
he established the record for fifty miles, flying this distance over the
sea in one hour and fifteen minutes, despite a strong wind which im-
peded his progress.
The Curtiss biplanes have taken the lead in advancing the science
of
aviation
along practical lines during the year.
In cross-country
flights, bomb
dropping
experiments,
demonstrations of aerial sharp-
shooting, flying from deck of a vessel, and probably most important
of all, in transmitting a wireless message from an aeroplane in flight,
the Curtiss biplanes have done more to demonstrate the practicability
of the aeroplane as an adjunct to military and naval forces, than any
other flyer.
It will be further demonstrated here by others of the men
who have been pioneers in these experiments.
CURTISS BIPLANE.
L HOLO DY

AVIATION MEET, SAN FRANCISCO, 1911
Eugene B. Fly
Eugene B. Ely, who is to fly here, while the youngest of the avi-
ators flying Curtiss biplanes, has rapidly forged to the front among the
best known aviators of the world.
He has two distinctions which mark
him out among aviators.
He learned to fly without instruction, that is,
by just flying, and he was the first man to demonstrate the heavier
than air flying machine before the kite loving people of Japan.
When the aeroplane
was first demonstrated a success, Ely was
known on the Pacific Coast best known as a driver of racing automo-
biles.
He was one of the first Americans to become an expert auto
driver.
Determined to get into the air game early, he took charge of
an aeroplane owned by a wealthy westerner who had nobody to fly it.
He later purchased the machine and by his successful flights attracted
He made a well paying
the attention of 19 i Id the Curtis own Hom de te iportant
tour of Japan in 1910.
events, and was chosen to fly the specially built Curtiss machine at
Belmont Park, N. Y.
When it was proposed by the Curtiss Company to demonstrate
the possibility of an aeroplane flying from a ship at sea, Ely was se-
lected to try the experiment and on
November 14, 1910, he
lected to try the fightinent and eck of the U.S. Cruiser Birmingham.
The cruiser was anchored off Hampton Roads, about five miles from
Willoughby Beach, and the weather was such that all hope of flight was
abandoned by naval authorities, when Ely and his mechanician began
a motor test.
the
signal
Immediately afterwards when the rain ceased, Ely gave
and the machine was released, running rapidly down the
starting way.
His machine dipped until the wheels touched the water,
splashing enough to rip a piece out of his propellor.
He continued the
flight, however, distancing the torpedo boats, and made a safe land-
ing on a narrow strip of beach.
Due to this experiment, the naval au-
thorities have taken up aeronautics.

OFFICIAL SOUVENIR PROGRAM
Charles H. Willarn
The fact that Charles F. Willard is to fly at this meet is significant.
The art of mechanical flights is too new to permit of reference to vet-
eran aviators, but Willard can boast of being the first man in America,
aside from the Wrights and Glenn H. Curtiss, to successfully operate
an aeroplane.
The first public flights in this country were made by
Curtiss less than two years ago.
Mr. Curtiss'
first pupil was Wil-
lard, whose ability to handle the dangerous flying machine was dem-
onstrated with his first attempt at flight.
He was trained by Curtiss at
Mineola, and the success which attended his efforts brought him into
national fame. Ile had made but few flights before he manipulated
the aeroplane so successful as almost to equal the work of Curtiss, the
master.
By profession Willard is a mechanical engineer, but his inclina-
tions are more in the nature of doing things than of planning them.
That he is fearless is attested to by the fact that he is an aeroplanist.
Although the danger attending the operation of a flying machine is
generally appreciated, no one but those who have flown have any con-
ception of the real extent of the danger.
After the fateful accident to
the government aeroplane at Ft. Myer, in which Lieut. Selfridge was
killed and Orville Wright seriously injured, experts decided that a col-
umn of air
thrown upward by a small wooden shed shattered the
propellor, causing the wreck of the machine.
Willard has the eye of an
eagle, and his instincts regarding the wind and possible danger are
similar to that of the birds themselves.
The machine
which Willard will fly here is the one with which
Curtiss won the Scientific American trophy and with which Willard
himself won several events at the Los Angeles Meet in January, 1910.
His exhibition here will include all of the events which go to make
up an aviation meet.

AVIATION MEET, SAN FRANCISCO, 1911
James Ranley
Probably one of the most daring aerialists is Mr. James Radley, of
England, who has achieved international fame as an aviator.
At the Aviation Meet at Lanark,
Scotland, on August 15, 1910,
Radley performed what is probably the most marvelous descent ever
attempted by any aviator.
Due to the sudden back-firing of his en-
gine, followed immediately by the breaking of his crank shaft, Radley
pointed his aeroplane (a Bleriot) earthward and descended 1300 feet on
a perpendicular plane in the wonderful time of nine seconds, right-
ing his plane and alighting safely.
The barograph record showed a
perfectly vertical line in recording this descent.
Radley, at the same meet, captured the speed record for one mile
straight away, covering the distance at the terrific speed of 77.6 miles
per hour.
On his Bleriot he again flew a mile straight away in 47 and
2-3 seconds, equivalent to 75.95 miles per hour.
The world's record for
speed had been previously held by Morane, who, at Rheims, traveled at
the rate of 65.3 miles per hour over a 7½-mile course.
At this same meet Radley established the British record for quick
start, leaving the ground in fifty-seven feet run.
BLERIOT MONOPLANE.
—Photo by Amer.
ress Ass.

In case the world's speed record is exceeded more than once, for each suc-

OFFICIAL SOUVENIR PROGRAM
Schedule and Conditima of Prizes-Ont'd
DURATION CONTEST
First Prize
.$3000.00
Second Prize
1000.00
Third Prize
500.00
Conditions:
To qualify,
an
aviator
must be in
the alr
at least thirty
minutes during the period
set apart for "Hourly Contests" each day of
the meet.
The aviator who is in the air the greatest length of time during the official
hours of the entire meet, according to the Judge's record, will receive the first
prize.
The aviator who is in the air the second greatest length of time during the
official hours of the entire meet, according to the Judge's record, will receive
the second prize.
The aviator who is in the air the third greatest length of time during the
official hours of the entire meet, according to the Judge's record, will receive the
third prize.
Each aviator qualifying daily will be credited with the actual time in the
air during the "Hourly Contest" period, together with the time in the air during
the speed contests, and the time in the air during the passenger carrying con-
tests.
SHORT START
The aviator leaving the ground in the shortest distance will receive the
first prize of $50.00.
This is a prize as scheduled.
If there be less than three aviators competing for this prize, it will be with-
drawn for that day, there being no competition.
ACCURACY
The aviator making the best score for accuracy in landing will receive the
first prize of $50.00.
This is a prize on days as scheduled.
If there
be less than three aviators competing for this prize, it will be
withdrawn for that day, there being no competition.

BIPLANE.

The amounts of any and all prizes offered herein, for either novices
or professionals, are subject to increase, decrease, withdrawal, total can-
cellation, or any change whatsoever at the option of the Aviation Board,
at any time.

A Oribute to the Marift Aern Ulth
This Meet is international in character and the management de-
sires to express to the Pacific Aero Club of San Francisco, its appreci-
ation for the earnest and hearty co-operation which that Aero Club has
accorded throughout the Meet and preparations therefor. It is due to
this club to state at this time that the sanction under which the Meet
is held was obtained for the Citizens' Committee by the Pacific Aero,
Club. It is hoped that the efforts of this Aero Club will meet with
the hearty support of the citizens of San Francisco to the end that
aviation will be promoted here and as an expression of the thanks of
the community for the work which the Pacific Aero Club has done.
General Informatim
This international Meet is a citizens'
affair.
At its head are the
most prominent citizens of San Francisco and California. There has not
been spent nor will there be spent one dollar for promotion.
All of the
officers are giving their time and efforts without remuneration of any
sort.
Should there be any profit it will be returned to those citizens
who have underwritten the expenses of the Meet, in the form of pro
rata dividends.
